qText: The mater will be delighted to see you again   after all those years,
speaker: John Cavendish

qText: Your mother keeps well?
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qText: Oh, yes. I suppose you know that she has married again?
speaker: John Cavendish

qText: Rotten little bounder too!
speaker: John Cavendish

qText: I can tell you, Hastings, it's making life jolly difficult for us. As for Evie   you remember Evie?
speaker: John Cavendish

qText: No.
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qText: Oh, I suppose she was after your time. She's the mater's factotum, companion, Jack of all trades! A great sport   old Evie! Not precisely young and beautiful, but as game as they make them.
speaker: John Cavendish

qText: You were going to say      ?
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qText: Oh, this fellow! He turned up from nowhere, on the pretext of being a second cousin or something of Evie's, though she didn't seem particularly keen to acknowledge the relationship. The fellow is an absolute outsider, anyone can see that. He's got a great black beard, and wears patent leather boots in all weathers! But the mater cottoned to him at once, took him on as secretary   you know how she's always running a hundred societies?
speaker: John Cavendish
menTexts: ['this fellow', 'He', "a second cousin or something of Evie's", 'she', 'The fellow', 'He', 'the mater', 'him', 'him', 'you', 'she']
menEnts: [['Alfred Inglethorp'], ['Alfred Inglethorp'], ['Mr. Inglethorp'], ['Evelyn Howard'], ['Alfred Inglethorp'], ['Alfred Inglethorp'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Alfred Inglethorp'], ['Alfred Inglethorp'], ['Mr. Hastings'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp']]

qText: Well, of course the war has turned the hundreds into thousands. No doubt the fellow was very useful to her. But you could have knocked us all down with a feather when, three months ago, she suddenly announced that she and Alfred were engaged! The fellow must be at least twenty years younger than she is! It's simply bare-faced fortune hunting; but there you are   she is her own mistress, and she's married him.
speaker: John Cavendish
menEnts: [['Alfred Inglethorp'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Mr. Hastings'], ['Mary Cavendish', 'John Cavendish', 'Evelyn Howard'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Alfred Inglethorp'], ['Alfred Inglethorp'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Mr. Hastings'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Alfred Inglethorp']]

qText: It must be a difficult situation for you all.
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qText: Difficult! It's damnable!
speaker: John Cavendish

qText: Got a drop or two of petrol still, you see,
speaker: John Cavendish

qText: Mainly owing to the mater's activities.
speaker: John Cavendish

qText: I'm afraid you'll find it very quiet down here, Hastings.
speaker: John Cavendish

qText: My dear fellow, that's just what I want.
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qText: Oh, it's pleasant enough if you want to lead the idle life. I drill with the volunteers twice a week, and lend a hand at the farms. My wife works regularly    on the land'. She is up at five every morning to milk, and keeps at it steadily until lunchtime. It's a jolly good life taking it all round   if it weren't for that fellow Alfred Inglethorp!
speaker: John Cavendish

qText: I wonder if we've time to pick up Cynthia. No, she'll have started from the hospital by now.
speaker: John Cavendish

qText: Cynthia! That's not your wife?
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qText: No, Cynthia is a prot  g  e of my mother's, the daughter of an old schoolfellow of hers, who married a rascally solicitor. He came a cropper, and the girl was left an orphan and penniless. My mother came to the rescue, and Cynthia has been with us nearly two years now. She works in the Red Cross Hospital at Tadminster, seven miles away.
speaker: John Cavendish

qText: Tell me   you're drawn to something? Everyone is   usually something absurd.

qText: You'll laugh at me.
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qText: Perhaps.
speaker: Mary Cavendish

qText: Well, I've always had a secret hankering to be a detective!
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qText: The real thing   Scotland Yard? Or Sherlock Holmes?
speaker: Mary Cavendish

qText: Oh, Sherlock Holmes by all means. But really, seriously, I am awfully drawn to it. I came across a man in Belgium once, a very famous detective, and he quite inflamed me. He was a marvellous little fellow. He used to say that all good detective work was a mere matter of method. My system is based on his   though of course I have progressed rather further. He was a funny little man, a great dandy, but wonderfully clever.
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qText: John will show you your room. Supper is at half-past seven. We have given up late dinner for some time now. Lady Tadminster, our Member's wife   she was the late Lord Abbotsbury's daughter   does the same. She agrees with me that one must set an example of economy. We are quite a war household; nothing is wasted here   every scrap of waste paper, even, is saved and sent away in sacks.

qText: Poirot,
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qText: I wish you would tell me why you wanted to know if Mrs. Inglethorp ate well last night? I have been turning it over in my mind, but I can't see how it has anything to do with the matter?
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qText: I do not mind telling you   though, as you know, it is not my habit to explain until the end is reached. The present contention is that Mrs. Inglethorp died of strychnine poisoning, presumably administered in her coffee.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: Yes?
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qText: Well, what time was the coffee served?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: About eight o'clock.
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qText: Therefore she drank it between then and half-past eight   certainly not much later. Well, strychnine is a fairly rapid poison. Its effects would be felt very soon, probably in about an hour. Yet, in Mrs. Inglethorp's case, the symptoms do not manifest themselves until five o'clock the next morning: nine hours! But a heavy meal, taken at about the same time as the poison, might retard its effects, though hardly to that extent. Still, it is a possibility to be taken into account. But, according to you, she ate very little for supper, and yet the symptoms do not develop until early the next morning! Now that is a curious circumstance, my friend. Something may arise at the autopsy to explain it. In the meantime, remember it.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: Well, sir, I happened to be going along the hall outside yesterday

The door was shut, but the mistress was speaking very sharp and clear, and I heard what she said quite plainly.

qText: No, sir.
speaker: Dorcas

qText: Are you quite sure?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: Oh, yes, sir.
speaker: Dorcas

qText: Has anyone else in the house got a green dress?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: Miss Cynthia has a green evening dress.
speaker: Dorcas

qText: Light or dark green?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: A light green, sir; a sort of chiffon, they call it.
speaker: Dorcas

qText: Ah, that is not what I want. And nobody else has anything green?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: No, sir   not that I know of.
speaker: Dorcas

qText: Good, we will leave that and pass on. Have you any reason to believe that your mistress was likely to take a sleeping powder last night?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: Not _last_ night, sir, I know she didn't.
speaker: Dorcas

qText: Why do you know so positively?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: Because the box was empty. She took the last one two days ago, and she didn't have any more made up.
speaker: Dorcas

qText: You are quite sure of that?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: Positive, sir.
speaker: Dorcas

qText: Then that is cleared up! By the way, your mistress didn't ask you to sign any paper yesterday?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: To sign a paper? No, sir.
speaker: Dorcas

qText: When Mr. Hastings and Mr. Lawrence came in yesterday evening, they found your mistress busy writing letters. I suppose you can give me no idea to whom these letters were addressed?
speaker: Hercule Poirot
menEnts: [['Mr. Hastings'], ['Mr. Lawrence Cavendish'], ['Mr. Hastings', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Dorcas']]

qText: I'm afraid I couldn't, sir. I was out in the evening. Perhaps Annie could tell you, though she's a careless girl. Never cleared the coffee-cups away last night. That's what happens when I'm not here to look after things.
speaker: Dorcas

qText: Since they have been left, Dorcas, leave them a little longer, I pray you. I should like to examine them.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: Very well, sir.
speaker: Dorcas

qText: What time did you go out last evening?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: About six o'clock, sir.
speaker: Dorcas

qText: Thank you, Dorcas, that is all I have to ask you.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: I have been admiring these flower beds. How many gardeners are employed here, by the way?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: Only three now, sir. Five, we had, before the war, when it was kept as a gentleman's place should be. I wish you could have seen it then, sir. A fair sight it was. But now there's only old Manning, and young William, and a new-fashioned woman gardener in breeches and such-like. Ah, these are dreadful times!
speaker: Dorcas

qText: The good times will come again, Dorcas. At least, we hope so. Now, will you send Annie to me here?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: Yes, sir. Thank you, sir.
speaker: Dorcas

qText: How did you know that Mrs. Inglethorp took sleeping powders?
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qText: And about the lost key and the duplicate?
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qText: One thing at a time. As to the sleeping powders, I knew by this.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: Where did you find it?
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qText: In the wash-stand drawer in Mrs. Inglethorp's bedroom. It was Number Six of my catalogue.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: But I suppose, as the last powder was taken two days ago, it is not of much importance?
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qText: Probably not, but do you notice anything that strikes you as peculiar about this box?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: No, I can't say that I do.
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qText: Look at the label.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: No, I see nothing unusual.
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qText: Not the fact that there is no chemist's name?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: Ah!
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qText: To be sure, that is odd!
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qText: Have you ever known a chemist to send out a box like that, without his printed name?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: No, I can't say that I have.
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qText: Yet the explanation is quite simple. So do not intrigue yourself, my friend.
speaker: Hercule Poirot
refExp: Poirot damped my ardour by remarking

qText: I sent for you, Annie, because I thought you might be able to tell me something about the letters Mrs. Inglethorp wrote last night. How many were there? And can you tell me any of the names and addresses?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: There were four letters, sir. One was to Miss Howard, and one was to Mr. Wells, the lawyer, and the other two I don't think I remember, sir   oh, yes, one was to Ross's, the caterers in Tadminster. The other one, I don't remember.
speaker: Annie

qText: Think,
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: I'm sorry, sir, but it's clean gone. I don't think I can have noticed it.
speaker: Annie

qText: It does not matter,
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: Now I want to ask you about something else. There is a saucepan in Mrs. Inglethorp's room with some cocoa in it. Did she have that every night?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: Yes, sir, it was put in her room every evening, and she warmed it up in the night   whenever she fancied it.
speaker: Annie

qText: What was it? Plain cocoa?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: Yes, sir, made with milk, with a teaspoonful of sugar, and two teaspoonfuls of rum in it.
speaker: Annie

qText: Who took it to her room?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: I did, sir.
speaker: Annie

qText: Always?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: Yes, sir.
speaker: Annie

qText: At what time?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: When I went to draw the curtains, as a rule, sir.
speaker: Annie

qText: Did you bring it straight up from the kitchen then?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: No, sir, you see there's not much room on the gas stove, so cook used to make it early, before putting the vegetables on for supper. Then I used to bring it up, and put it on the table by the swing door, and take it into her room later.
speaker: Annie

qText: The swing door is in the left wing, is it not?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: Yes, sir.
speaker: Annie

qText: And the table, is it on this side of the door, or on the farther   servants' side?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: It's this side, sir.
speaker: Annie

qText: What time did you bring it up last night?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: About quarter-past seven, I should say, sir.
speaker: Annie

qText: And when did you take it into Mrs. Inglethorp's room?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: When I went to shut up, sir. About eight o'clock. Mrs. Inglethorp came up to bed before I'd finished.
speaker: Annie

qText: Then, between seven-fifteen and eight o'clock, the cocoa was standing on the table in the left wing?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: Yes, sir.
speaker: Annie

qText: And if there _was_ salt in it, sir, it wasn't me. I never took the salt near it.
speaker: Annie

qText: What makes you think there was salt in it?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: Seeing it on the tray, sir.
speaker: Annie

qText: You saw some salt on the tray?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: Yes. Coarse kitchen salt, it looked. I never noticed it when I took the tray up, but when I came to take it into the mistress's room I saw it at once, and I suppose I ought to have taken it down again, and asked cook to make some fresh. But I was in a hurry, because Dorcas was out, and I thought maybe the cocoa itself was all right, and the salt had only gone on the tray. So I dusted it off with my apron, and took it in.
speaker: Annie

qText: When you went into Mrs. Inglethorp's room, was the door leading into Miss Cynthia's room bolted?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: Oh! Yes, sir; it always was. It had never been opened.
speaker: Annie

qText: And the door into Mr. Inglethorp's room? Did you notice if that was bolted too?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: I couldn't rightly say, sir; it was shut but I couldn't say whether it was bolted or not.
speaker: Annie

qText: When you finally left the room, did Mrs. Inglethorp bolt the door after you?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: No, sir, not then, but I expect she did later. She usually did lock it at night. The door into the passage, that is.
speaker: Annie

qText: Did you notice any candle grease on the floor when you did the room yesterday?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: Candle grease? Oh, no, sir. Mrs. Inglethorp didn't have a candle, only a reading-lamp.
speaker: Annie

qText: Then, if there had been a large patch of candle grease on the floor, you think you would have been sure to have seen it?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: Yes, sir, and I would have taken it out with a piece of blotting-paper and a hot iron.
speaker: Annie

qText: Did your mistress ever have a green dress?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: No, sir.
speaker: Annie

qText: Nor a mantle, nor a cape, nor a   how do you call it?   a sports coat?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: Not green, sir.
speaker: Annie

qText: Nor anyone else in the house?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: No, sir.
speaker: Annie

qText: You are sure of that?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: Quite sure.
speaker: Annie

qText: _Bien!_ That is all I want to know. Thank you very much.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: Poirot,
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qText: I congratulate you! This is a great discovery.
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qText: What is a great discovery?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: Why, that it was the cocoa and not the coffee that was poisoned. That explains everything! Of course it did not take effect until the early morning, since the cocoa was only drunk in the middle of the night.
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qText: So you think that the cocoa   mark well what I say, Hastings, the _cocoa_   contained strychnine?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: Of course! That salt on the tray, what else could it have been?
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qText: It might have been salt,
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: You are not pleased with me, _mon ami?_
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: My dear Poirot,
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qText: it is not for me to dictate to you. You have a right to your own opinion, just as I have to mine.
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qText: A most admirable sentiment,
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: Now I have finished with this room. By the way, whose is the smaller desk in the corner?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: Mr. Inglethorp's.
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qText: Ah!
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: Locked. But perhaps one of Mrs. Inglethorp's keys would open it.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: _Voil  !_ It is not the key, but it will open it at a pinch.
speaker: Hercule Poirot
refExp: He tried several twisting and turning them with a practiced hand and finally uttering

qText: Decidedly, he is a man of method, this Mr. Inglethorp!
speaker: Hercule Poirot
refExp: he did not examine them merely remarking

qText: There were no stamps in his desk, but there might have been, eh, _mon ami?_ There might have been? Yes
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: this boudoir has nothing more to tell us. It did not yield much. Only this.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: Where did you find this?
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qText: In the waste-paper basket. You recognise the handwriting?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: Yes, it is Mrs. Inglethorp's. But what does it mean?
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qText: I cannot say   but it is suggestive.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: Come,
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: now to examine the coffee-cups!
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: My dear Poirot! What on earth is the good of that, now that we know about the cocoa?
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qText: Oh, _l   l  !_ That miserable cocoa!
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: And, anyway,
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qText: as Mrs. Inglethorp took her coffee upstairs with her, I do not see what you expect to find, unless you consider it likely that we shall discover a packet of strychnine on the coffee tray!
speaker: Mr. Hastings
menEnts: [['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Hercule Poirot'], ['Hercule Poirot'], ['Mr. Hastings', 'Hercule Poirot']]

qText: Come, come, my friend,
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: _Ne vous f  chez pas!_ Allow me to interest myself in my coffee-cups, and I will respect your cocoa. There! Is it a bargain?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: So Mrs. Cavendish stood by the tray   and poured out. Yes. Then she came across to the window where you sat with Mademoiselle Cynthia. Yes. Here are the three cups. And the cup on the mantelpiece, half drunk, that would be Mr. Lawrence Cavendish's. And the one on the tray?
speaker: Hercule Poirot
menEnts: [['Mary Cavendish'], ['Mary Cavendish'], ['Mr. Hastings'], ['Miss Murdoch'], ['Mr. Lawrence Cavendish']]

qText: John Cavendish's. I saw him put it down there.
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qText: Good. One, two, three, four, five   but where, then, is the cup of Mr. Inglethorp?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: He does not take coffee.
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qText: Then all are accounted for. One moment, my friend.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: _Bien!_
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: It is evident! I had an idea   but clearly I was mistaken. Yes, altogether I was mistaken. Yet it is strange. But no matter!
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: Breakfast is ready,
speaker: John Cavendish

qText: You will breakfast with us, Monsieur Poirot?
speaker: John Cavendish
menEnts: [['Hercule Poirot'], ['Mary Cavendish', 'John Cavendish', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Mr. Hastings'], ['Hercule Poirot']]

qText: May I ask how things are proceeding?
speaker: John Cavendish

qText: Do your investigations point to my mother having died a natural death   or   or must we prepare ourselves for the worst?
speaker: John Cavendish
menEnts: [['Hercule Poirot'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Mary Cavendish', 'John Cavendish', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish']]

qText: I think, Mr. Cavendish,
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: that you would do well not to buoy yourself up with any false hopes. Can you tell me the views of the other members of the family?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: My brother Lawrence is convinced that we are making a fuss over nothing. He says that everything points to its being a simple case of heart failure.
speaker: John Cavendish
menEnts: [['Mr. Lawrence Cavendish'], ['John Cavendish', 'Mr. Hastings'], ['Mr. Lawrence Cavendish']]

qText: He does, does he? That is very interesting   very interesting,
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: And Mrs. Cavendish?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: I have not the least idea what my wife's views on the subject are.
speaker: John Cavendish

qText: I told you, didn't I, that Mr. Inglethorp has returned?
speaker: John Cavendish
refExp: John broke the rather awkward silence by saying

qText: It's an awkward position for all of us. Of course one has to treat him as usual   but, hang it all, one's gorge does rise at sitting down to eat with a possible murderer!
speaker: John Cavendish
menEnts: [['Mary Cavendish', 'John Cavendish', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish'], ['Alfred Inglethorp']]

qText: I quite understand. It is a very difficult situation for you, Mr. Cavendish. I would like to ask you one question. Mr. Inglethorp's reason for not returning last night was, I believe, that he had forgotten the latch-key. Is not that so?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: Yes.
speaker: John Cavendish

qText: I suppose you are quite sure that the latch-key _was_ forgotten   that he did not take it after all?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: I have no idea. I never thought of looking. We always keep it in the hall drawer. I'll go and see if it's there now.
speaker: John Cavendish

qText: No, no, Mr. Cavendish, it is too late now. I am certain that you would find it. If Mr. Inglethorp did take it, he has had ample time to replace it by now.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: But do you think
speaker: John Cavendish

qText: I think nothing. If anyone had chanced to look this morning before his return, and seen it there, it would have been a valuable point in his favour. That is all.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: Do not worry,
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: I assure you that you need not let it trouble you. Since you are so kind, let us go and have some breakfast.
speaker: Hercule Poirot
menEnts: [['John Cavendish'], ['John Cavendish'], ['John Cavendish'], ['John Cavendish'], ['John Cavendish', 'Mr. Hastings', 'Hercule Poirot']]

qText: Yes, I've got the most beastly headache.
speaker: Miss Murdoch

qText: Have another cup of coffee, mademoiselle?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: It will revive you. It is unparalleled for the _mal de t  te_.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: No sugar,
speaker: Miss Murdoch

qText: No sugar? You abandon it in the war-time, eh?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: No, I never take it in coffee.
speaker: Miss Murdoch

qText: _Sacr  !_
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: Mr. Wells to see you, sir,
speaker: Dorcas
addressee: ['Mary Cavendish', 'Hercule Poirot', 'Alfred Inglethorp', 'John Cavendish', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Mr. Hastings']

qText: Show him into my study.
speaker: John Cavendish

qText: My mother's lawyer,
speaker: John Cavendish

qText: He is also Coroner   you understand. Perhaps you would like to come with me?
speaker: John Cavendish

qText: There will be an inquest then?
speaker: Mr. Hastings
refExp: I took the opportunity of whispering to Poirot

qText: What is it? You are not attending to what I say.
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qText: It is true, my friend. I am much worried.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: Why?
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qText: Because Mademoiselle Cynthia does not take sugar in her coffee.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: What? You cannot be serious?
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qText: But I am most serious. Ah, there is something there that I do not understand. My instinct was right.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: What instinct?
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qText: The instinct that led me to insist on examining those coffee-cups. _Chut!_ no more now!
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: You will understand, Wells,
speaker: John Cavendish

qText: that this is all strictly private. We are still hoping that there will turn out to be no need for investigation of any kind.
speaker: John Cavendish

qText: Quite so, quite so,
speaker: Mr. Wells

qText: I wish we could have spared you the pain and publicity of an inquest, but of course it's quite unavoidable in the absence of a doctor's certificate.
speaker: Mr. Wells

qText: Yes, I suppose so.
speaker: John Cavendish

qText: Clever man, Bauerstein. Great authority on toxicology, I believe.
speaker: Mr. Wells

qText: Indeed,
speaker: John Cavendish

qText: Shall we have to appear as witnesses   all of us, I mean?
speaker: John Cavendish
menEnts: [['Mary Cavendish', 'John Cavendish', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Mr. Hastings'], ['Mary Cavendish', 'John Cavendish', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Mr. Hastings']]

qText: You, of course   and ah   er   Mr.   er   Inglethorp.
speaker: Mr. Wells

qText: Any other evidence will be simply confirmatory, a mere matter of form.
speaker: Mr. Wells

qText: I see.
speaker: John Cavendish

qText: If you know of nothing to the contrary,
speaker: Mr. Wells

qText: I had thought of Friday. That will give us plenty of time for the doctor's report. The post-mortem is to take place to-night, I believe?
speaker: Mr. Wells

qText: Yes.
speaker: John Cavendish

qText: Then that arrangement will suit you?
speaker: Mr. Wells

qText: Perfectly.
speaker: John Cavendish

qText: I need not tell you, my dear Cavendish, how distressed I am at this most tragic affair.
speaker: Mr. Wells

qText: Can you give us no help in solving it, monsieur?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: I?
speaker: Mr. Wells

qText: Yes, we heard that Mrs. Inglethorp wrote to you last night. You should have received the letter this morning.
speaker: Hercule Poirot
menEnts: [['John Cavendish', 'Mr. Hastings', 'Hercule Poirot'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Mr. Wells'], ['Mr. Wells']]

qText: I did, but it contains no information. It is merely a note asking me to call upon her this morning, as she wanted my advice on a matter of great importance.
speaker: Mr. Wells

qText: She gave you no hint as to what that matter might be?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: Unfortunately, no.
speaker: Mr. Wells

qText: That is a pity,
speaker: John Cavendish

qText: A great pity,
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: Mr. Wells, there is one thing I should like to ask you   that is, if it is not against professional etiquette. In the event of Mrs. Inglethorp's death, who would inherit her money?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: The knowledge will be public property very soon, so if Mr. Cavendish does not object
speaker: Mr. Wells
refExp: The lawyer hesitated a moment and then replied

qText: Not at all,
speaker: John Cavendish

qText: I do not see any reason why I should not answer your question. By her last will, dated August of last year, after various unimportant legacies to servants, etc., she gave her entire fortune to her stepson, Mr. John Cavendish.
speaker: Mr. Wells

qText: Was not that   pardon the question, Mr. Cavendish   rather unfair to her other stepson, Mr. Lawrence Cavendish?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: No, I do not think so. You see, under the terms of their father's will, while John inherited the property, Lawrence, at his stepmother's death, would come into a considerable sum of money. Mrs. Inglethorp left her money to her elder stepson, knowing that he would have to keep up Styles. It was, to my mind, a very fair and equitable distribution.
speaker: Mr. Wells
menEnts: [['Hercule Poirot'], ['John Cavendish', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish'], ['John Cavendish'], ['Mr. Lawrence Cavendish'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['John Cavendish'], ['John Cavendish']]

qText: I see. But I am right in saying, am I not, that by your English law that will was automatically revoked when Mrs. Inglethorp remarried?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: As I was about to proceed, Monsieur Poirot, that document is now null and void.
speaker: Mr. Wells

qText: _Hein!_
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: Was Mrs. Inglethorp herself aware of that fact?
speaker: Hercule Poirot
refExp: He reflected for a moment and then asked

qText: I do not know. She may have been.
speaker: Mr. Wells

qText: She was,
speaker: John Cavendish

qText: We were discussing the matter of wills being revoked by marriage only yesterday.
speaker: John Cavendish

qText: Ah! One more question, Mr. Wells. You say
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: Had Mrs. Inglethorp, then, made several former wills?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: On an average, she made a new will at least once a year,
speaker: Mr. Wells

qText: She was given to changing her mind as to her testamentary dispositions, now benefiting one, now another member of her family.
speaker: Mr. Wells

qText: Suppose,
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: that, unknown to you, she had made a new will in favour of someone who was not, in any sense of the word, a member of the family   we will say Miss Howard, for instance   would you be surprised?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: Not in the least.
speaker: Mr. Wells

qText: Ah!
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: Do you think Mrs. Inglethorp made a will leaving all her money to Miss Howard?
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qText: No.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: Then why did you ask?
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qText: Hush!
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: Will you come with us, Monsieur Poirot? We are going through my mother's papers. Mr. Inglethorp is quite willing to leave it entirely to Mr. Wells and myself.
speaker: John Cavendish

qText: Which simplifies matters very much,
speaker: Mr. Wells

qText: As technically, of course, he was entitled
speaker: Mr. Wells

qText: We will look through the desk in the boudoir first,
speaker: John Cavendish

qText: and go up to her bedroom afterwards. She kept her most important papers in a purple despatch-case, which we must look through carefully.
speaker: John Cavendish

qText: Yes,
speaker: Mr. Wells

qText: it is quite possible that there may be a later will than the one in my possession.

qText: Do as I ask you. Afterwards you shall question as much as you please.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: Very well.
speaker: John Cavendish

qText: Dorcas, will you tell Manning to come round and speak to me here.
speaker: John Cavendish

qText: Yes, sir.
speaker: Dorcas

qText: Come inside, Manning,
speaker: John Cavendish

qText: I want to speak to you.
speaker: John Cavendish

qText: Manning,
speaker: John Cavendish

qText: this gentleman will put some questions to you which I want you to answer.
speaker: John Cavendish

qText: Yessir,
speaker: Manning

qText: You were planting a bed of begonias round by the south side of the house yesterday afternoon, were you not, Manning?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: Yes, sir, me and Willum.
speaker: Manning

qText: And Mrs. Inglethorp came to the window and called you, did she not?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: Yes, sir, she did.
speaker: Manning

qText: Tell me in your own words exactly what happened after that.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: Well, sir, nothing much. She just told Willum to go on his bicycle down to the village, and bring back a form of will, or such-like   I don't know what exactly   she wrote it down for him.
speaker: Manning

qText: Well?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: Well, he did, sir.
speaker: Manning

qText: And what happened next?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: We went on with the begonias, sir.
speaker: Manning

qText: Did not Mrs. Inglethorp call you again?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: Yes, sir, both me and Willum, she called.
speaker: Manning

qText: And then?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: She made us come right in, and sign our names at the bottom of a long paper   under where she'd signed.
speaker: Manning

qText: Did you see anything of what was written above her signature?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: No, sir, there was a bit of blotting paper over that part.
speaker: Manning

qText: And you signed where she told you?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: Yes, sir, first me and then Willum.
speaker: Manning

qText: What did she do with it afterwards?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: Well, sir, she slipped it into a long envelope, and put it inside a sort of purple box that was standing on the desk.
speaker: Manning

qText: What time was it when she first called you?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: About four, I should say, sir.
speaker: Manning

qText: Not earlier? Couldn't it have been about half-past three?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: No, I shouldn't say so, sir. It would be more likely to be a bit after four   not before it.
speaker: Manning

qText: Thank you, Manning, that will do,
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: Good heavens!
speaker: John Cavendish

qText: What an extraordinary coincidence.
speaker: John Cavendish

qText: How   a coincidence?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: That my mother should have made a will on the very day of her death!
speaker: John Cavendish

qText: Are you so sure it is a coincidence, Cavendish?
speaker: Mr. Wells
refExp: Mr Wells cleared his throat and remarked

qText: What do you mean?
speaker: John Cavendish

qText: Your mother, you tell me, had a violent quarrel with   someone yesterday afternoon
speaker: Mr. Wells

qText: What do you mean?
speaker: John Cavendish

qText: In consequence of that quarrel, your mother very suddenly and hurriedly makes a new will. The contents of that will we shall never know. She told no one of its provisions. This morning, no doubt, she would have consulted me on the subject   but she had no chance. The will disappears, and she takes its secret with her to her grave. Cavendish, I much fear there is no coincidence there. Monsieur Poirot, I am sure you agree with me that the facts are very suggestive.
speaker: Mr. Wells
menEnts: [['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Hercule Poirot', 'John Cavendish', 'Mr. Wells', 'Mr. Hastings'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['John Cavendish'], ['Hercule Poirot'], ['Hercule Poirot']]

qText: Suggestive, or not,
speaker: John Cavendish

qText: we are most grateful to Monsieur Poirot for elucidating the matter. But for him, we should never have known of this will. I suppose, I may not ask you, monsieur, what first led you to suspect the fact?
speaker: John Cavendish

qText: A scribbled over old envelope, and a freshly planted bed of begonias.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: Evie!
speaker: John Cavendish

qText: Excuse me, Wells.
speaker: John Cavendish

qText: Miss Howard,
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qText: Ah, I am glad she has come. There is a woman with a head and a heart too, Hastings. Though the good God gave her no beauty!
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: Started the moment I got the wire. Just come off night duty. Hired car. Quickest way to get here.
speaker: Evelyn Howard

qText: Have you had anything to eat this morning, Evie?
speaker: John Cavendish

qText: No.
speaker: Evelyn Howard

qText: I thought not. Come along, breakfast's not cleared away yet, and they'll make you some fresh tea.
speaker: John Cavendish

qText: Look after her, Hastings, will you? Wells is waiting for me. Oh, here's Monsieur Poirot. He's helping us, you know, Evie.
speaker: John Cavendish
menEnts: [['Evelyn Howard'], ['Mr. Hastings'], ['Hercule Poirot'], ['Hercule Poirot'], ['Mary Cavendish', 'John Cavendish', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish'], ['Evelyn Howard'], ['Evelyn Howard']]

qText: What do you mean   helping us?
speaker: Evelyn Howard

qText: Helping us to investigate.
speaker: John Cavendish

qText: Nothing to investigate. Have they taken him to prison yet?
speaker: Evelyn Howard

qText: Taken who to prison?
speaker: John Cavendish

qText: Who? Alfred Inglethorp, of course!
speaker: Evelyn Howard

qText: My dear Evie, do be careful. Lawrence is of the opinion that my mother died from heart seizure.
speaker: John Cavendish

qText: More fool, Lawrence!
speaker: Evelyn Howard

qText: Of course Alfred Inglethorp murdered poor Emily   as I always told you he would.
speaker: Evelyn Howard

qText: My dear Evie, don't shout so. Whatever we may think or suspect, it is better to say as little as possible for the present. The inquest isn't until Friday.
speaker: John Cavendish

qText: Not until fiddlesticks!
speaker: Evelyn Howard

qText: You're all off your heads. The man will be out of the country by then. If he's any sense, he won't stay here tamely and wait to be hanged.
speaker: Evelyn Howard
menEnts: [['John Cavendish', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish'], ['John Cavendish', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish'], ['Mr. Inglethorp'], ['Alfred Inglethorp'], ['Alfred Inglethorp']]

qText: I know what it is,
speaker: Evelyn Howard

qText: you've been listening to the doctors. Never should. What do they know? Nothing at all   or just enough to make them dangerous. I ought to know   my own father was a doctor. That little Wilkins is about the greatest fool that even I have ever seen. Heart seizure! Sort of thing he would say. Anyone with any sense could see at once that her husband had poisoned her. I always said he'd murder her in her bed, poor soul. Now he's done it. And all you can do is to murmur silly things about
speaker: Evelyn Howard
menEnts: [['John Cavendish'], ['Dr. Wilkins', 'Dr. Bauerstein'], ['Dr. Wilkins', 'Dr. Bauerstein'], ['Dr. Wilkins', 'Dr. Bauerstein'], ['Dr. Wilkins'], ['Alfred Inglethorp'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Alfred Inglethorp'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Alfred Inglethorp'], ['John Cavendish']]

qText: and
speaker: Evelyn Howard

qText: You ought to be ashamed of yourself, John Cavendish.
speaker: Evelyn Howard

qText: What do you want me to do?
speaker: John Cavendish

qText: Dash it all, Evie, I can't haul him down to the local police station by the scruff of his neck.
speaker: John Cavendish

qText: Well, you might do something. Find out how he did it. He's a crafty beggar. Dare say he soaked fly papers. Ask cook if she's missed any.
speaker: Evelyn Howard

qText: Mademoiselle,
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: I want to ask you something.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: Ask away,
speaker: Evelyn Howard

qText: I want to be able to count upon your help.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: I'll help you to hang Alfred with pleasure,
speaker: Evelyn Howard

qText: Hanging's too good for him. Ought to be drawn and quartered, like in good old times.
speaker: Evelyn Howard

qText: We are at one then,
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: for I, too, want to hang the criminal.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: Alfred Inglethorp?
speaker: Evelyn Howard

qText: Him, or another.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: No question of another. Poor Emily was never murdered until _he_ came along. I don't say she wasn't surrounded by sharks   she was. But it was only her purse they were after. Her life was safe enough. But along comes Mr. Alfred Inglethorp   and within two months   hey presto!
speaker: Evelyn Howard
menEnts: [['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Alfred Inglethorp'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['John Cavendish', 'Mary Cavendish', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Mary Cavendish', 'John Cavendish', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Alfred Inglethorp']]

qText: Believe me, Miss Howard,
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: if Mr. Inglethorp is the man, he shall not escape me. On my honour, I will hang him as high as Haman!
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: That's better,
speaker: Evelyn Howard

qText: But I must ask you to trust me. Now your help may be very valuable to me. I will tell you why. Because, in all this house of mourning, yours are the only eyes that have wept.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: If you mean that I was fond of her   yes, I was. You know, Emily was a selfish old woman in her way. She was very generous, but she always wanted a return. She never let people forget what she had done for them   and, that way she missed love. Don't think she ever realized it, though, or felt the lack of it. Hope not, anyway. I was on a different footing. I took my stand from the first.
speaker: Evelyn Howard
menEnts: [['Hercule Poirot'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Hercule Poirot'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp']]

qText: She didn't understand   was very offended sometimes. Said I was foolishly proud. It wasn't that   but I couldn't explain. Anyway, I kept my self-respect. And so, out of the whole bunch, I was the only one who could allow myself to be fond of her. I watched over her. I guarded her from the lot of them, and then a glib-tongued scoundrel comes along, and pooh! all my years of devotion go for nothing.
speaker: Evelyn Howard
menEnts: [['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Mary Cavendish', 'John Cavendish', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish'], ['Alfred Inglethorp']]

qText: I understand, mademoiselle, I understand all you feel. It is most natural. You think that we are lukewarm   that we lack fire and energy   but trust me, it is not so.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: Look here, what's going to happen when these two meet?
speaker: John Cavendish

qText: I've told Mary to keep them apart if she can.
speaker: John Cavendish

qText: Will she be able to do so?
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qText: The Lord only knows. There's one thing, Inglethorp himself won't be too keen on meeting her.
speaker: John Cavendish

qText: You've got the keys still, haven't you, Poirot?
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qText: My mother kept most of her important papers in this despatch-case, I believe,
speaker: John Cavendish

qText: Permit me. I locked it, out of precaution, this morning.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: But it's not locked now.
speaker: John Cavendish

qText: Impossible!
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: See.
speaker: John Cavendish
refExp: John lifted the lid as he spoke

qText: _Milles tonnerres!_
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: And I   who have both the keys in my pocket!
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: _Eh voil   une affaire!_ This lock has been forced.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: Who? That is the question. Why? Ah, if I only knew. When? Since I was here an hour ago. As to the door being locked, it is a very ordinary lock. Probably any other of the doorkeys in this passage would fit it.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: See here, it was like this,
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: There was something in that case   some piece of evidence, slight in itself perhaps, but still enough of a clue to connect the murderer with the crime. It was vital to him that it should be destroyed before it was discovered and its significance appreciated. Therefore, he took the risk, the great risk, of coming in here. Finding the case locked, he was obliged to force it, thus betraying his presence. For him to take that risk, it must have been something of great importance.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: Ah!
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: That, I do not know! A document of some kind, without doubt, possibly the scrap of paper Dorcas saw in her hand yesterday afternoon. And I
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: miserable animal that I am! I guessed nothing! I have behaved like an imbecile! I should never have left that case here. I should have carried it away with me. Ah, triple pig! And now it is gone. It is destroyed   but is it destroyed? Is there not yet a chance   we must leave no stone unturned
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: What has happened to your extraordinary little friend, Mr. Hastings? He has just rushed past me like a mad bull.
speaker: Mary Cavendish

qText: He's rather upset about something,
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qText: They haven't met yet, have they?
speaker: Mr. Hastings
refExp: I endeavoured to try and turn the conversation by saying

qText: Who?
speaker: Mary Cavendish

qText: Mr. Inglethorp and Miss Howard.
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qText: Do you think it would be such a disaster if they did meet?
speaker: Mary Cavendish

qText: Well, don't you?
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qText: No.
speaker: Mary Cavendish

qText: I should like to see a good flare up. It would clear the air. At present we are all thinking so much, and saying so little.
speaker: Mary Cavendish
menEnts: [['Mary Cavendish', 'Alfred Inglethorp', 'John Cavendish', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Mr. Hastings']]

qText: John doesn't think so,
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qText: He's anxious to keep them apart.
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qText: Oh, John!
speaker: Mary Cavendish

qText: Old John's an awfully good sort.
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qText: You are loyal to your friend. I like you for that.
speaker: Mary Cavendish
refExp: She studied me curiously for a minute or two and then said

qText: Aren't you my friend too?
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qText: I am a very bad friend.
speaker: Mary Cavendish

qText: Why do you say that?
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qText: Because it is true. I am charming to my friends one day, and forget all about them the next.
speaker: Mary Cavendish

qText: Yet you seem to be invariably charming to Dr. Bauerstein!
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qText: My dear fellow,
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qText: is this wise? Surely you don't want the whole house to know of this occurrence? You are actually playing into the criminal's hands.
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qText: You think so, Hastings?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: I am sure of it.
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qText: Well, well, my friend, I will be guided by you.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: Good. Although, unfortunately, it is a little too late now.
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qText: Sure.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: Well,
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: let us go, _mon ami_.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: You have finished here?
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qText: For the moment, yes. You will walk back with me to the village?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: Willingly.
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qText: Excuse me, mademoiselle, one minute.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: Yes?
speaker: Miss Murdoch

qText: Did you ever make up Mrs. Inglethorp's medicines?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: No.
speaker: Miss Murdoch

qText: Only her powders?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: Oh, yes, I did make up some sleeping powders for her once.
speaker: Miss Murdoch

qText: These?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: Can you tell me what they were? Sulphonal? Veronal?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: No, they were bromide powders.
speaker: Miss Murdoch

qText: Ah! Thank you, mademoiselle; good morning.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: My friend,
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: I have a little idea, a very strange, and probably utterly impossible idea. And yet   it fits in.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: So that is the explanation of the blank label on the box,
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qText: Very simple, as you said. I really wonder that I did not think of it myself.
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qText: They have made one more discovery, _l  -bas_,
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: Mr. Wells told me as we were going upstairs.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: What was it?
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qText: Locked up in the desk in the boudoir, they found a will of Mrs. Inglethorp's, dated before her marriage, leaving her fortune to Alfred Inglethorp. It must have been made just at the time they were engaged. It came quite as a surprise to Wells   and to John Cavendish also. It was written on one of those printed will forms, and witnessed by two of the servants   not Dorcas.
speaker: Hercule Poirot
menEnts: [['John Cavendish', 'Mr. Wells'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Alfred Inglethorp'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp', 'Alfred Inglethorp'], ['Mr. Wells'], ['John Cavendish'], ['Dorcas']]

qText: Did Mr. Inglethorp know of it?
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qText: He says not.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: One might take that with a grain of salt,
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qText: All these wills are very confusing. Tell me, how did those scribbled words on the envelope help you to discover that a will was made yesterday afternoon?
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qText: _Mon ami_, have you ever, when writing a letter, been arrested by the fact that you did not know how to spell a certain word?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: Yes, often. I suppose everyone has.
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qText: Exactly. And have you not, in such a case, tried the word once or twice on the edge of the blotting-paper, or a spare scrap of paper, to see if it looked right? Well, that is what Mrs. Inglethorp did. You will notice that the word    possessed' is spelt first with one    s' and subsequently with two   correctly. To make sure, she had further tried it in a sentence, thus:
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: Now, what did that tell me? It told me that Mrs. Inglethorp had been writing the word    possessed' that afternoon, and, having the fragment of paper found in the grate fresh in my mind, the possibility of a will   (a document almost certain to contain that word)   occurred to me at once. This possibility was confirmed by a further circumstance. In the general confusion, the boudoir had not been swept that morning, and near the desk were several traces of brown mould and earth. The weather had been perfectly fine for some days, and no ordinary boots would have left such a heavy deposit.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: I strolled to the window, and saw at once that the begonia beds had been newly planted. The mould in the beds was exactly similar to that on the floor of the boudoir, and also I learnt from you that they _had_ been planted yesterday afternoon. I was now sure that one, or possibly both of the gardeners   for there were two sets of footprints in the bed   had entered the boudoir, for if Mrs. Inglethorp had merely wished to speak to them she would in all probability have stood at the window, and they would not have come into the room at all. I was now quite convinced that she had made a fresh will, and had called the two gardeners in to witness her signature. Events proved that I was right in my supposition.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: That was very ingenious,
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qText: I must confess that the conclusions I drew from those few scribbled words were quite erroneous.
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qText: You gave too much rein to your imagination. Imagination is a good servant, and a bad master. The simplest explanation is always the most likely.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: Another point   how did you know that the key of the despatch-case had been lost?
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qText: I did not know it. It was a guess that turned out to be correct. You observed that it had a piece of twisted wire through the handle. That suggested to me at once that it had possibly been wrenched off a flimsy key-ring. Now, if it had been lost and recovered, Mrs. Inglethorp would at once have replaced it on her bunch; but on her bunch I found what was obviously the duplicate key, very new and bright, which led me to the hypothesis that somebody else had inserted the original key in the lock of the despatch-case.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: Yes,
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qText: Alfred Inglethorp, without doubt.
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qText: You are very sure of his guilt?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: Well, naturally. Every fresh circumstance seems to establish it more clearly.
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qText: On the contrary,
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: there are several points in his favour.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: Oh, come now!
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qText: Yes.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: I see only one.
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qText: And that?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: That he was not in the house last night.
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qText: Bad shot!' as you English say! You have chosen the one point that to my mind tells against him.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: How is that?
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qText: Because if Mr. Inglethorp knew that his wife would be poisoned last night, he would certainly have arranged to be away from the house. His excuse was an obviously trumped up one. That leaves us two possibilities: either he knew what was going to happen or he had a reason of his own for his absence.
speaker: Hercule Poirot
menEnts: [['Alfred Inglethorp'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Alfred Inglethorp'], ['Alfred Inglethorp'], ['Alfred Inglethorp'], ['Alfred Inglethorp'], ['Alfred Inglethorp'], ['Alfred Inglethorp']]

qText: And that reason?
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qText: How should I know? Discreditable, without doubt. This Mr. Inglethorp, I should say, is somewhat of a scoundrel   but that does not of necessity make him a murderer.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: We do not agree, eh?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: Well, let us leave it. Time will show which of us is right. Now let us turn to other aspects of the case. What do you make of the fact that all the doors of the bedroom were bolted on the inside?
speaker: Hercule Poirot
menEnts: [['Mr. Hastings', 'Hercule Poirot'], ['Mr. Hastings', 'Hercule Poirot'], ['Mr. Hastings', 'Hercule Poirot'], ['Mr. Hastings']]

qText: Well
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qText: One must look at it logically.
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qText: True.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: I should put it this way. The doors _were_ bolted   our own eyes have told us that   yet the presence of the candle grease on the floor, and the destruction of the will, prove that during the night someone entered the room. You agree so far?
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qText: Perfectly. Put with admirable clearness. Proceed.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: Well,
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qText: as the person who entered did not do so by the window, nor by miraculous means, it follows that the door must have been opened from inside by Mrs. Inglethorp herself. That strengthens the conviction that the person in question was her husband. She would naturally open the door to her own husband.
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qText: Why should she? She had bolted the door leading into his room   a most unusual proceeding on her part   she had had a most violent quarrel with him that very afternoon. No, he was the last person she would admit.
speaker: Hercule Poirot
menEnts: [['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Alfred Inglethorp'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Alfred Inglethorp'], ['Alfred Inglethorp'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp']]

qText: But you agree with me that the door must have been opened by Mrs. Inglethorp herself?
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qText: There is another possibility. She may have forgotten to bolt the door into the passage when she went to bed, and have got up later, towards morning, and bolted it then.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: Poirot, is that seriously your opinion?
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qText: No, I do not say it is so, but it might be. Now, to turn to another feature, what do you make of the scrap of conversation you overheard between Mrs. Cavendish and her mother-in-law?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: I had forgotten that,
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qText: That is as enigmatical as ever. It seems incredible that a woman like Mrs. Cavendish, proud and reticent to the last degree, should interfere so violently in what was certainly not her affair.
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qText: Precisely. It was an astonishing thing for a woman of her breeding to do.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: It is certainly curious,
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qText: Still, it is unimportant, and need not be taken into account.
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qText: What have I always told you? Everything must be taken into account. If the fact will not fit the theory   let the theory go.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: Well, we shall see,
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qText: Yes, we shall see.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: Look, Poirot!
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qText: _Tiens!_
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: It is Mr. Mace, from the chemist's shop. He is coming here.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: A little minute,
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: I come.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: Oh, Mr. Poirot, I'm sorry for the inconvenience, but I heard that you'd just come back from the Hall?
speaker: Mr. Mace

qText: Yes, we have.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: It's all over the village about old Mrs. Inglethorp dying so suddenly. They do say
speaker: Mr. Mace

qText: that it's poison?
speaker: Mr. Mace

qText: Only the doctors can tell us that, Mr. Mace.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: Yes, exactly   of course
speaker: Mr. Mace

qText: Just tell me this, Mr. Poirot, it isn't   it isn't strychnine, is it?
speaker: Mr. Mace

qText: Yes,
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: He will have evidence to give at the inquest.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: Not now, not now, _mon ami_. I have need of reflection. My mind is in some disorder   which is not well.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: It is well. The bad moment has passed. Now all is arranged and classified. One must never permit confusion. The case is not clear yet   no. For it is of the most complicated! It puzzles _me_. _Me_, Hercule Poirot! There are two facts of significance.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: And what are they?
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qText: The first is the state of the weather yesterday. That is very important.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: But it was a glorious day!
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qText: Poirot, you're pulling my leg!
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qText: Not at all. The thermometer registered 80 degrees in the shade. Do not forget that, my friend. It is the key to the whole riddle!
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: And the second point?
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qText: The important fact that Monsieur Inglethorp wears very peculiar clothes, has a black beard, and uses glasses.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: Poirot, I cannot believe you are serious.
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qText: I am absolutely serious, my friend.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: But this is childish!
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qText: No, it is very momentous.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: And supposing the Coroner's jury returns a verdict of Wilful Murder against Alfred Inglethorp. What becomes of your theories, then?
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qText: They would not be shaken because twelve stupid men had happened to make a mistake! But that will not occur. For one thing, a country jury is not anxious to take responsibility upon itself, and Mr. Inglethorp stands practically in the position of local squire. Also,
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: _I_ should not allow it!
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: _You_ would not allow it?
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qText: No.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: Oh, yes, _mon ami_, I would do what I say.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: In all this, you see, I think of that poor Mrs. Inglethorp who is dead. She was not extravagantly loved   no. But she was very good to us Belgians   I owe her a debt.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: You'm from the Hall, bain't you?
speaker: An Aged Rustic

qText: Yes. I'm looking for a friend of mine whom I thought might have walked this way.
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qText: A little chap? As waves his hands when he talks? One of them Belgies from the village?
speaker: An Aged Rustic
menTexts: ['A little chap', 'his', 'he', 'One of them Belgies from the village']

qText: Yes,
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qText: He has been here, then?
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qText: Oh, ay, he's been here, right enough. More'n once too. Friend of yours, is he? Ah, you gentlemen from the Hall   you'm a pretty lot!
speaker: An Aged Rustic
menEnts: [['Hercule Poirot'], ['Hercule Poirot'], ['Hercule Poirot'], ['Mr. Hastings', 'Hercule Poirot', 'Inglethorp'], ['Mr. Hastings', 'Hercule Poirot', 'Inglethorp']]

qText: Why, do the gentlemen from the Hall come here often?
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qText: _One_ does, mister. Naming no names, mind. And a very liberal gentleman too! Oh, thank you, sir, I'm sure.
speaker: An Aged Rustic

qText: Is it possible that she could have swallowed the poison by accident?
speaker: Mr. Wells
addressee: ['Dorcas', 'Hercule Poirot', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Dr. Wilkins', 'Mr. Mace', 'Mary Cavendish', 'Manning', 'Mr. Inglethorp', 'Japp', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Dr. Bauerstein', 'Mr. Hastings', 'John Cavendish', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Summerhaye']

qText: I should consider it very unlikely. Strychnine is not used for domestic purposes, as some poisons are, and there are restrictions placed on its sale.
speaker: Dr. Bauerstein
addressee: ['Dorcas', 'Hercule Poirot', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Dr. Wilkins', 'Mr. Mace', 'Mary Cavendish', 'Manning', 'Mr. Inglethorp', 'Japp', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Mr. Hastings', 'John Cavendish', 'Mr. Wells', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Summerhaye']

qText: Does anything in your examination lead you to determine how the poison was administered?
speaker: Mr. Wells
addressee: ['Dorcas', 'Hercule Poirot', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Dr. Wilkins', 'Mr. Mace', 'Mary Cavendish', 'Manning', 'Mr. Inglethorp', 'Japp', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Dr. Bauerstein', 'Mr. Hastings', 'John Cavendish', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Summerhaye']

qText: No.
speaker: Dr. Bauerstein
addressee: ['Dorcas', 'Hercule Poirot', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Dr. Wilkins', 'Mr. Mace', 'Mary Cavendish', 'Manning', 'Mr. Inglethorp', 'Japp', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Mr. Hastings', 'John Cavendish', 'Mr. Wells', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Summerhaye']

qText: You arrived at Styles before Dr. Wilkins, I believe?
speaker: Mr. Wells
addressee: ['Dorcas', 'Hercule Poirot', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Dr. Wilkins', 'Mr. Mace', 'Mary Cavendish', 'Manning', 'Mr. Inglethorp', 'Japp', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Dr. Bauerstein', 'Mr. Hastings', 'John Cavendish', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Summerhaye']

qText: That is so. The motor met me just outside the lodge gates, and I hurried there as fast as I could.
speaker: Dr. Bauerstein
addressee: ['Dorcas', 'Hercule Poirot', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Dr. Wilkins', 'Mr. Mace', 'Mary Cavendish', 'Manning', 'Mr. Inglethorp', 'Japp', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Mr. Hastings', 'John Cavendish', 'Mr. Wells', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Summerhaye']

qText: Will you relate to us exactly what happened next?
speaker: Mr. Wells
addressee: ['Dorcas', 'Hercule Poirot', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Dr. Wilkins', 'Mr. Mace', 'Mary Cavendish', 'Manning', 'Mr. Inglethorp', 'Japp', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Dr. Bauerstein', 'Mr. Hastings', 'John Cavendish', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Summerhaye']
menEnts: [['Dr. Bauerstein'], ['Cynthia', 'Dorcas', 'Dr. Bauerstein', 'Dr. Wilkins', 'Evie', 'Hercule Poirot', 'Inglethorp', 'Japp', 'John Cavendish', 'Manning', 'Mary Cavendish', 'Mr. Hastings', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Mr. Mace', 'Mr. Wells']]

qText: I entered Mrs. Inglethorp's room. She was at that moment in a typical tetanic convulsion. She turned towards me, and gasped out:
speaker: Dr. Bauerstein
addressee: ['Dorcas', 'Hercule Poirot', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Dr. Wilkins', 'Mr. Mace', 'Mary Cavendish', 'Manning', 'Mr. Inglethorp', 'Japp', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Mr. Hastings', 'John Cavendish', 'Mr. Wells', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Summerhaye']

qText: Could the strychnine have been administered in Mrs. Inglethorp's after-dinner coffee which was taken to her by her husband?
speaker: Mr. Wells
addressee: ['Dorcas', 'Hercule Poirot', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Dr. Wilkins', 'Mr. Mace', 'Mary Cavendish', 'Manning', 'Mr. Inglethorp', 'Japp', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Dr. Bauerstein', 'Mr. Hastings', 'John Cavendish', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Summerhaye']

qText: Possibly, but strychnine is a fairly rapid drug in its action. The symptoms appear from one to two hours after it has been swallowed. It is retarded under certain conditions, none of which, however, appear to have been present in this case. I presume Mrs. Inglethorp took the coffee after dinner about eight o'clock, whereas the symptoms did not manifest themselves until the early hours of the morning, which, on the face of it, points to the drug having been taken much later in the evening.
speaker: Dr. Bauerstein
addressee: ['Dorcas', 'Hercule Poirot', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Dr. Wilkins', 'Mr. Mace', 'Mary Cavendish', 'Manning', 'Mr. Inglethorp', 'Japp', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Mr. Hastings', 'John Cavendish', 'Mr. Wells', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Summerhaye']

qText: Mrs. Inglethorp was in the habit of drinking a cup of cocoa in the middle of the night. Could the strychnine have been administered in that?
speaker: Mr. Wells
addressee: ['Dorcas', 'Hercule Poirot', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Dr. Wilkins', 'Mr. Mace', 'Mary Cavendish', 'Manning', 'Mr. Inglethorp', 'Japp', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Dr. Bauerstein', 'Mr. Hastings', 'John Cavendish', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Summerhaye']

qText: No, I myself took a sample of the cocoa remaining in the saucepan and had it analysed. There was no strychnine present.
speaker: Dr. Bauerstein
addressee: ['Dorcas', 'Hercule Poirot', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Dr. Wilkins', 'Mr. Mace', 'Mary Cavendish', 'Manning', 'Mr. Inglethorp', 'Japp', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Mr. Hastings', 'John Cavendish', 'Mr. Wells', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Summerhaye']

qText: How did you know?
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qText: Listen.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: I should say
speaker: Dr. Bauerstein
addressee: ['Dorcas', 'Hercule Poirot', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Dr. Wilkins', 'Mr. Mace', 'Mary Cavendish', 'Manning', 'Mr. Inglethorp', 'Japp', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Mr. Hastings', 'John Cavendish', 'Mr. Wells', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Summerhaye']

qText: that I would have been considerably surprised at any other result.
speaker: Dr. Bauerstein
addressee: ['Dorcas', 'Hercule Poirot', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Dr. Wilkins', 'Mr. Mace', 'Mary Cavendish', 'Manning', 'Mr. Inglethorp', 'Japp', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Mr. Hastings', 'John Cavendish', 'Mr. Wells', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Summerhaye']

qText: Why?
speaker: Mr. Wells
addressee: ['Dorcas', 'Hercule Poirot', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Dr. Wilkins', 'Mr. Mace', 'Mary Cavendish', 'Manning', 'Mr. Inglethorp', 'Japp', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Dr. Bauerstein', 'Mr. Hastings', 'John Cavendish', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Summerhaye']

qText: Simply because strychnine has an unusually bitter taste. It can be detected in a solution of one in seventy thousand, and can only be disguised by some strongly flavoured substance. Cocoa would be quite powerless to mask it.
speaker: Dr. Bauerstein
addressee: ['Dorcas', 'Hercule Poirot', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Dr. Wilkins', 'Mr. Mace', 'Mary Cavendish', 'Manning', 'Mr. Inglethorp', 'Japp', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Mr. Hastings', 'John Cavendish', 'Mr. Wells', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Summerhaye']

qText: No. Coffee has a bitter taste of its own which would probably cover the taste of strychnine.
speaker: Dr. Bauerstein
addressee: ['Dorcas', 'Hercule Poirot', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Dr. Wilkins', 'Mr. Mace', 'Mary Cavendish', 'Manning', 'Mr. Inglethorp', 'Japp', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Mr. Hastings', 'John Cavendish', 'Mr. Wells', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Summerhaye']

qText: Then you consider it more likely that the drug was administered in the coffee, but that for some unknown reason its action was delayed.
speaker: Mr. Wells
addressee: ['Dorcas', 'Hercule Poirot', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Dr. Wilkins', 'Mr. Mace', 'Mary Cavendish', 'Manning', 'Mr. Inglethorp', 'Japp', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Dr. Bauerstein', 'Mr. Hastings', 'John Cavendish', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Summerhaye']

qText: Yes, but, the cup being completely smashed, there is no possibility of analyzing its contents.
speaker: Dr. Bauerstein
addressee: ['Dorcas', 'Hercule Poirot', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Dr. Wilkins', 'Mr. Mace', 'Mary Cavendish', 'Manning', 'Mr. Inglethorp', 'Japp', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Mr. Hastings', 'John Cavendish', 'Mr. Wells', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Summerhaye']

qText: I should like to make a suggestion if I may?
speaker: Mr. Lawrence Cavendish
addressee: ['Dorcas', 'Hercule Poirot', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Dr. Wilkins', 'Mr. Mace', 'Mary Cavendish', 'Manning', 'Mr. Inglethorp', 'Japp', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Dr. Bauerstein', 'Mr. Hastings', 'John Cavendish', 'Mr. Wells', 'Summerhaye']

qText: Certainly, Mr. Cavendish, we are here to arrive at the truth of this matter, and welcome anything that may lead to further elucidation.
speaker: Mr. Wells
addressee: ['Dorcas', 'Hercule Poirot', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Dr. Wilkins', 'Mr. Mace', 'Mary Cavendish', 'Manning', 'Mr. Inglethorp', 'Japp', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Dr. Bauerstein', 'Mr. Hastings', 'John Cavendish', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Summerhaye']
menEnts: [['Mr. Lawrence Cavendish'], ['Dorcas', 'Hercule Poirot', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Dr. Wilkins', 'Mr. Mace', 'Mary Cavendish', 'Manning', 'Mr. Inglethorp', 'Japp', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Dr. Bauerstein', 'Mr. Hastings', 'John Cavendish']]

qText: It is just an idea of mine,
speaker: Mr. Lawrence Cavendish
addressee: ['Dorcas', 'Hercule Poirot', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Dr. Wilkins', 'Mr. Mace', 'Mary Cavendish', 'Manning', 'Mr. Inglethorp', 'Japp', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Dr. Bauerstein', 'Mr. Hastings', 'John Cavendish', 'Mr. Wells', 'Summerhaye']

qText: Of course I may be quite wrong, but it still seems to me that my mother's death might be accounted for by natural means.
speaker: Mr. Lawrence Cavendish
addressee: ['Dorcas', 'Hercule Poirot', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Dr. Wilkins', 'Mr. Mace', 'Mary Cavendish', 'Manning', 'Mr. Inglethorp', 'Japp', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Dr. Bauerstein', 'Mr. Hastings', 'John Cavendish', 'Mr. Wells', 'Summerhaye']

qText: How do you make that out, Mr. Cavendish?
speaker: Mr. Wells
addressee: ['Dorcas', 'Hercule Poirot', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Dr. Wilkins', 'Mr. Mace', 'Mary Cavendish', 'Manning', 'Mr. Inglethorp', 'Japp', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Dr. Bauerstein', 'Mr. Hastings', 'John Cavendish', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Summerhaye']

qText: My mother, at the time of her death, and for some time before it, was taking a tonic containing strychnine.
speaker: Mr. Lawrence Cavendish
addressee: ['Dorcas', 'Hercule Poirot', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Dr. Wilkins', 'Mr. Mace', 'Mary Cavendish', 'Manning', 'Mr. Inglethorp', 'Japp', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Dr. Bauerstein', 'Mr. Hastings', 'John Cavendish', 'Mr. Wells', 'Summerhaye']

qText: Ah!
speaker: Mr. Wells
addressee: ['Dorcas', 'Hercule Poirot', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Dr. Wilkins', 'Mr. Mace', 'Mary Cavendish', 'Manning', 'Mr. Inglethorp', 'Japp', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Dr. Bauerstein', 'Mr. Hastings', 'John Cavendish', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Summerhaye']

qText: I believe,
speaker: Mr. Lawrence Cavendish
addressee: ['Dorcas', 'Hercule Poirot', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Dr. Wilkins', 'Mr. Mace', 'Mary Cavendish', 'Manning', 'Mr. Inglethorp', 'Japp', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Dr. Bauerstein', 'Mr. Hastings', 'John Cavendish', 'Mr. Wells', 'Summerhaye']

qText: that there have been cases where the cumulative effect of a drug, administered for some time, has ended by causing death. Also, is it not possible that she may have taken an overdose of her medicine by accident?
speaker: Mr. Lawrence Cavendish
addressee: ['Dorcas', 'Hercule Poirot', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Dr. Wilkins', 'Mr. Mace', 'Mary Cavendish', 'Manning', 'Mr. Inglethorp', 'Japp', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Dr. Bauerstein', 'Mr. Hastings', 'John Cavendish', 'Mr. Wells', 'Summerhaye']

qText: This is the first we have heard of the deceased taking strychnine at the time of her death. We are much obliged to you, Mr. Cavendish.
speaker: Mr. Wells
addressee: ['Dorcas', 'Hercule Poirot', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Dr. Wilkins', 'Mr. Mace', 'Mary Cavendish', 'Manning', 'Mr. Inglethorp', 'Japp', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Dr. Bauerstein', 'Mr. Hastings', 'John Cavendish', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Summerhaye']
menEnts: [['Dr. Bauerstein', 'Dr. Wilkins', 'Cynthia', 'Dorcas', 'Evie', 'Hercule Poirot', 'Inglethorp', 'Japp', 'John Cavendish', 'Manning', 'Mary Cavendish', 'Mr. Hastings', 'Mr. Mace', 'Mr. Wells'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Dr. Bauerstein', 'Dr. Wilkins', 'Cynthia', 'Dorcas', 'Evie', 'Hercule Poirot', 'Inglethorp', 'Japp', 'John Cavendish', 'Manning', 'Mary Cavendish', 'Mr. Hastings', 'Mr. Mace', 'Mr. Wells'], ['Mr. Lawrence Cavendish'], ['Mr. Lawrence Cavendish']]

qText: What Mr. Cavendish suggests is quite impossible. Any doctor would tell you the same. Strychnine is, in a certain sense, a cumulative poison, but it would be quite impossible for it to result in sudden death in this way. There would have to be a long period of chronic symptoms which would at once have attracted my attention. The whole thing is absurd.
speaker: Dr. Wilkins
addressee: ['Dorcas', 'Hercule Poirot', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Mr. Mace', 'Mary Cavendish', 'Manning', 'Mr. Inglethorp', 'Japp', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Dr. Bauerstein', 'Mr. Hastings', 'John Cavendish', 'Mr. Wells', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Summerhaye']
refExp: Dr Wilkins was recalled and ridiculed

qText: And the second suggestion? That Mrs. Inglethorp may have inadvertently taken an overdose?
speaker: Mr. Wells
addressee: ['Dorcas', 'Hercule Poirot', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Dr. Wilkins', 'Mr. Mace', 'Mary Cavendish', 'Manning', 'Mr. Inglethorp', 'Japp', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Dr. Bauerstein', 'Mr. Hastings', 'John Cavendish', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Summerhaye']

qText: Three, or even four doses, would not have resulted in death. Mrs. Inglethorp always had an extra large amount of medicine made up at a time, as she dealt with Coot's, the Cash Chemists in Tadminster. She would have had to take very nearly the whole bottle to account for the amount of strychnine found at the post-mortem.
speaker: Dr. Wilkins
addressee: ['Dorcas', 'Hercule Poirot', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Mr. Mace', 'Mary Cavendish', 'Manning', 'Mr. Inglethorp', 'Japp', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Dr. Bauerstein', 'Mr. Hastings', 'John Cavendish', 'Mr. Wells', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Summerhaye']

qText: Then you consider that we may dismiss the tonic as not being in any way instrumental in causing her death?
speaker: Mr. Wells
addressee: ['Dorcas', 'Hercule Poirot', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Dr. Wilkins', 'Mr. Mace', 'Mary Cavendish', 'Manning', 'Mr. Inglethorp', 'Japp', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Dr. Bauerstein', 'Mr. Hastings', 'John Cavendish', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Summerhaye']
menEnts: [['Cynthia', 'Dorcas', 'Dr. Bauerstein', 'Dr. Wilkins', 'Evie', 'Hercule Poirot', 'Inglethorp', 'Japp', 'John Cavendish', 'Manning', 'Mary Cavendish', 'Mr. Hastings', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Mr. Mace', 'Mr. Wells'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp']]

qText: Certainly. The supposition is ridiculous.
speaker: Dr. Wilkins
addressee: ['Dorcas', 'Hercule Poirot', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Mr. Mace', 'Mary Cavendish', 'Manning', 'Mr. Inglethorp', 'Japp', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Dr. Bauerstein', 'Mr. Hastings', 'John Cavendish', 'Mr. Wells', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Summerhaye']

qText: That, of course, is always possible,
speaker: Dr. Wilkins
addressee: ['Dorcas', 'Hercule Poirot', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Mr. Mace', 'Mary Cavendish', 'Manning', 'Mr. Inglethorp', 'Japp', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Dr. Bauerstein', 'Mr. Hastings', 'John Cavendish', 'Mr. Wells', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Summerhaye']

qText: That would have been the table by the bed?
speaker: Mr. Wells
addressee: ['Dorcas', 'Hercule Poirot', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Dr. Wilkins', 'Mr. Mace', 'Mary Cavendish', 'Manning', 'Mr. Inglethorp', 'Japp', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Dr. Bauerstein', 'Mr. Hastings', 'John Cavendish', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Summerhaye']

qText: I opened my door,
speaker: Mary Cavendish
addressee: ['Dorcas', 'Hercule Poirot', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Dr. Wilkins', 'Mr. Mace', 'Manning', 'Mr. Inglethorp', 'Japp', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Dr. Bauerstein', 'Mr. Hastings', 'John Cavendish', 'Mr. Wells', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Summerhaye']

qText: and listened. In a few minutes a bell rang violently. Dorcas came running down and woke my husband, and we all went to my mother-in-law's room, but it was locked
speaker: Mary Cavendish
addressee: ['Dorcas', 'Hercule Poirot', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Dr. Wilkins', 'Mr. Mace', 'Manning', 'Mr. Inglethorp', 'Japp', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Dr. Bauerstein', 'Mr. Hastings', 'John Cavendish', 'Mr. Wells', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Summerhaye']

qText: I really do not think we need trouble you further on that point. We know all that can be known of the subsequent happenings. But I should be obliged if you would tell us all you overheard of the quarrel the day before.
speaker: Mr. Wells
addressee: ['Dorcas', 'Hercule Poirot', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Dr. Wilkins', 'Mr. Mace', 'Mary Cavendish', 'Manning', 'Mr. Inglethorp', 'Japp', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Dr. Bauerstein', 'Mr. Hastings', 'John Cavendish', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Summerhaye']
menEnts: [['Cynthia', 'Dorcas', 'Dr. Bauerstein', 'Dr. Wilkins', 'Evie', 'Hercule Poirot', 'Inglethorp', 'Japp', 'John Cavendish', 'Manning', 'Mr. Hastings', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Mr. Mace', 'Mr. Wells'], ['Mary Cavendish'], ['Cynthia', 'Dorcas', 'Dr. Bauerstein', 'Dr. Wilkins', 'Evie', 'Hercule Poirot', 'Inglethorp', 'Japp', 'John Cavendish', 'Manning', 'Mr. Hastings', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Mr. Mace', 'Mr. Wells'], ['Mary Cavendish'], ['Cynthia', 'Dorcas', 'Dr. Bauerstein', 'Dr. Wilkins', 'Evie', 'Hercule Poirot', 'Inglethorp', 'Japp', 'John Cavendish', 'Manning', 'Mr. Hastings', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Mr. Mace', 'Mr. Wells'], ['Mary Cavendish']]

qText: I?
speaker: Mary Cavendish
addressee: ['Dorcas', 'Hercule Poirot', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Dr. Wilkins', 'Mr. Mace', 'Manning', 'Mr. Inglethorp', 'Japp', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Dr. Bauerstein', 'Mr. Hastings', 'John Cavendish', 'Mr. Wells', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Summerhaye']

qText: She is gaining time!
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qText: Yes. I understand,
speaker: Mr. Wells
addressee: ['Dorcas', 'Hercule Poirot', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Dr. Wilkins', 'Mr. Mace', 'Mary Cavendish', 'Manning', 'Mr. Inglethorp', 'Japp', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Dr. Bauerstein', 'Mr. Hastings', 'John Cavendish', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Summerhaye']

qText: that you were sitting reading on the bench just outside the long window of the boudoir. That is so, is it not?
speaker: Mr. Wells
addressee: ['Dorcas', 'Hercule Poirot', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Dr. Wilkins', 'Mr. Mace', 'Mary Cavendish', 'Manning', 'Mr. Inglethorp', 'Japp', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Dr. Bauerstein', 'Mr. Hastings', 'John Cavendish', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Summerhaye']

qText: Yes, that is so.
speaker: Mary Cavendish
addressee: ['Dorcas', 'Hercule Poirot', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Dr. Wilkins', 'Mr. Mace', 'Manning', 'Mr. Inglethorp', 'Japp', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Dr. Bauerstein', 'Mr. Hastings', 'John Cavendish', 'Mr. Wells', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Summerhaye']

qText: And the boudoir window was open, was it not?
speaker: Mr. Wells
addressee: ['Dorcas', 'Hercule Poirot', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Dr. Wilkins', 'Mr. Mace', 'Mary Cavendish', 'Manning', 'Mr. Inglethorp', 'Japp', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Dr. Bauerstein', 'Mr. Hastings', 'John Cavendish', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Summerhaye']

qText: Yes.

qText: It seems to me very simple. The room was dimly lighted. Dr. Bauerstein is much of my height and build, and, like me, wears a beard. In the dim light, and suffering as she was, my poor wife mistook him for me.
speaker: Mr. Inglethorp
addressee: ['Dorcas', 'Hercule Poirot', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Dr. Wilkins', 'Mr. Mace', 'Mary Cavendish', 'Manning', 'Japp', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Dr. Bauerstein', 'Mr. Hastings', 'John Cavendish', 'Mr. Wells', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Summerhaye']

qText: Ah!
